FRS_Method: GPS CARRIER PHASE STATIC RELATIVE POSITION

_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Other Grocery and Related Products Merchant Wholesalers

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Sysco Nashville is located at One Hermitage Plaza in West Nashville, Tennessee. This site is a food service distribution and storage facility. The site started operations in 1975 and currently has 384 employees.Sysco Nashville distributes products such as food service items.
Anhydrous Ammonia is the only chemical that is covered by EPA's 40 CFR 68.130 RMP standard, with an on-site inventory of 15,000 lbs. 
The ammonia is utilized as a refrigerant for cooling and freezing perishable items. 
This system is maintained inside of two engine rooms. The engine rooms are provided with continuous ventilation, and the equipment is monitored for temperature, pressure and ammonia leaks continuously 24 hrs/day. The facility is monitored by Security Guards 24 hrs/day.
Sysco Nashville strives to be an accepted part of the community by being a good neighbor and citizen. We focus each day on all applicable Laws and Regulations in order to protect the Health and Safety of our employees and our community.
The Clean Air Act Ammendments (Section 112(r) ) mandated by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) requires an Risk Management Plan (RMP) that requires covered sites to perform an Off-Site Consequence Analysis by determining its Worst Case Scenario and its Alternative Release Scenario.
The Worst Case was based on the highly unlikely scenario of a catastrophic failure of an Ammonia liquid receiver without any mitigation. This would consist of the release of 6,400 lbs.of Ammonia from the receiver vessel in a Ten minutes time period assuming the worst possible weather conditions. The toxic endpoint would be 1.0 miles downwind.
This scenario is used to help the LEPC to plan proper Emergency Response in the event of a release.
The Alternative Release Scenario is a more realistic scenario and is based on the incident history and system knowledge.
This scenario would be a Pipe failure causing the release of Ammonia into one of the refrigeration engine rooms.
PREVENTION PLAN:
Prevention o

f these type releases are dependent on proper handling of the chemical.
Sysco Nashville's Prevention Plan consists' of adhering to OHSA's Process Safety Management standard that:

IDENTIFIES POTENTIAL HAZARDS:
1) Conducting Process Hazard Analysis on our Ammonia refrigeration systems,
2) Reviewing MODIFICATIONS or changes to the system,
3) Conducting PRE-STARTUP SAFETY REVIEWS after a modification.

CONTROLS POTENTIAL HAZARDS BY:
1) Utilizing detailed OPERATING PROCEDURES,
2) Thoroughly TRAINING each employee who operates and maintains the system, and certifying that he/she can properly operate the system,
3) Identifying, inspecting, & testing system piping and equipment for proper MECHANICAL INTEGRITY,
4) Maintaining accurate PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION on the Ammonia hazards, the equipment design data, and the system operating philosophy,
5) Selecting only CONTRACTORS with safe work histories and keeping them informed of potential hazards and emergency plans,
6) Utilizing a HOT WORK PERMIT system to assure safe maintenance work on the equipment.

PROVIDES EMERGENCY RESPONSE BY:
1) Maintaining an EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN to detail the protocol for notification of management and response agencies, mitigation procedures, and evacuation procedures.

CONDUCTS AUDITS BY:
1) Completing INCIDENT INVESTIGATIONS on all incidents in order to prevent reccurence,
2) Completing COMPLIANCE AUDITS of the PSM program every 3 years.

These Prevention Plan elements are accomplished by utilizing EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION as much as possible.

MANAGEMENT STRUCTURE
We have the following Safety and Health staff to assure prevention activities are administered properly:
1) Safety Manager
2) Facility Services Manager
3) Refrigeration Technicians
4) Security Personnel
5) Warehouse Trainers
6) Transportation Trainers

ACCIDENT HISTORY
Sysco Nashville  has had no RMP reportable accidents in the last 5 years.

EMERGENCY ACTION PLAN
An Emergency Action Plan exists as described in the Prevention Pla

n section in the unlikely event that a release occurs.
Highly trained Response Teams handle the spills, leaks, fires and injuries.
